headline: President Trump dares Nancy Pelosi to send articles of impeachment to the Senate
subHeadline: House Speaker Pelosi threatens to delay impeachment trial; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld, co-host
utterances.utterance: Getting worse and worse every day. Hello, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Jesse Waters, and she carpools on a caterpillar, Dana Perino -- "The Five." So, by the way, it didn't feel like we're being impeached.

utterances.speaker: Donald Trump
utterances.utterance: By the way, it doesn't really feel like we're being impeached.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It's 'cause they call it impeachment light.

utterances.speaker: President Donald Trump
utterances.utterance: They call it impeachment light. It's impeachment light. I don't know about you, but I'm having a good time. It's crazy.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It's crazy. No surprise, the impeachment vote was as lopsided as a chipmunk's face with a toothache. We knew this ahead of time, yet we had to fake it. But when we're force-fed any story, it pays to see who's imitating who. And it's clear the Dems ape the media, no offense to apes, and the media apes the Dems. Both admit a phony rectitude, then a celebration.

utterances.speaker: Rep. Rashida Tlaib
utterances.utterance: Hey everyone, I'm on my way to the United States House floor to impeach President Trump. On behalf of my incredible district, 13 district strong. Let's do this.

utterances.speaker: Speaker Nancy Pelosi
utterances.utterance: Article one is adopted.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, The Washington Post's wish you a "Happy Impeach-mas." Isn't that cute? For the rest of us who don't live in their giddy world of ritual self-congratulation, we wonder, how dumb are they? Don't they know this isn't a win -? It's a win-lose-lose? A win for Trump in a lose-lose for the media and the Dems. Not only will the Senate reject this sham, Trump will turn the vote into a badge of honor and then sell replicas of it online. He should actually. Trump turns political and media hate into a burden he shares with you because the media hates you too. Meanwhile, thanks to its reckless use, impeachment becomes meaningless. Every time one party controls the House, impeachment is just another way to cry, "resist." Why not start at inauguration? They did. But at least the phony press is laid bare. We see them create stories from feelings, narratives from mind-reading to smear those outside their bubble. Ask yourself this: Why is the press and the Dems happy with a losing proposition? Because it makes them feel good, thinking that you feel bad. But if the Dems and the media want to celebrate, let them. Because it's like all those other make-believe wins that they savored collusion, Covington, Kavanaugh. After the sugar rush fades, they're in the exact same place, inept and lost, while everyone with real jobs and real interest goes to work. Yo Jesse, this is the best year any president has ever had. Plus, we get an impeachment. It -- this -- Christmas came early.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters, co-host
utterances.utterance: And you knew Trump was going to get impeachment. He'll get it again in the second term. Yeah, just going to happen.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I think we're going to get four impeachments.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters, co-host
utterances.utterance: We could, we could do that depending on what he does or doesn't do. Here's the thing. Pelosi, so funny. You know, your mother in church when you get scolded for laughing? We're supposed to take this seriously, Jimmy. And that's what this whole thing's been. It hasn't been disciplined. It hasn't been honorable. From the very beginning, these little secret, crazy little sessions they had with Schiff going, God knows what in his weird little basement. And then you had these people they bring up to insult President Trump's children. And they didn't convince one single Republican, not one. It just shows you how partisan this whole thing was. Permission to make an analogy, Greg?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I -- permission granted.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: They don't have any ammunition left. It's like the bad guy in the movie when he's firing, firing. Then click, click.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Throws the gun.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: They're out of ammo. And the good guy, that's Trump one, standing over the bad guy saying, now we're going to finish you off. And that's it. They should've at least saved impeachment for the second term. That's when the real scandals happen anyway. And listen, they've grown so much.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams, co-host
utterances.utterance: Was that a defense?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: Historically. Historically speaking --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It's true, though.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: No matter what, they throw out, a Mueller, impeachment. What's next? Another dossier? Women? A fifth impeachment? It's gotten absurd and the rest of the country knows it. And as you've said, think about the last couple months. I mean, you've had Phase One China, NAFTA, you've had blockbuster economic numbers, breaking records. Baghdadi's dead. Think about it. This guy's having the best fall we've ever seen. And the Democrats are just falling flat on their face.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Juan--

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Was that a defense?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: It was pretty airtight.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Why would you bring up women with -- I mean, forget -

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: It's going to be a Kavanaugh situation.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Let's leave it alone. You know what, I just cede the floor to you and I join you. Thank you, Jesse, appreciate that. But I do think that to somehow twist this around, that this is win for Trump. It's no big deal. I think you got to tie yourself in knots to do it because being impeached, folks, is not good. Third time in history, not good. Nobody wants to be impeached. I don't think the president wanted to win, but he's did. Guess what? Nancy Pelosi didn't want to do the impeachment. That is a very good speech --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: True, because she knew she was going to lose. [LAUGHS]

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Well, no, I think she said that he felt forced to. But remember, Steny Hoyer, he made a good speech last night on the floor. He said, three times Democrats voted not to impeach. It was only when things got to the point where --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: So, they tried four times already?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: But no, they didn't try. They --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: They tried three, you just said three times.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: They said they rejected it, Greg --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's what I mean. So, they were -- they approached it four times.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Right. Because he keeps getting himself in trouble. But Trump says he doesn't feel it today. He doesn't feel like he's being impeached. I think that says more about his distorted sense of reality than it says about the Democrats or the fact, because the reality is that plenty of things Trump does, I don't like, and you know that. But they are not impeachable. When he talks about, you know, John Dingell going to hell. I just -- I don't like it. Not impeachable.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Never heard that joke before?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: It's not a joke when you're talking about a dead man. Going after dead people. John McCain, John Dingell --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Trump doesn't see live, dead, white, black, male, or female. He insults everybody.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: We're into the fourth year of this, Juan --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: He doesn't see women. Not -- no, no. Not Trump --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: He doesn't see anything you see --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Here's the thing. Here's the thing. There is such a thing as abuse of power. There is such a thing as obstructing Congress --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: Didn't happen, didn't happen.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- Real cases that legitimately justify impeachment.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: All right. So, they -- at least, Juan, admit it, they've been -- they've tried to impeach him four times. So, we got that out of them. Dana?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino, co-host
utterances.utterance: Well, to go back to Rashid Talib, which you started with. She's a Congresswoman from Michigan who started off her Congressional tenure as a freshman, that won in 2018 by saying we're going to impeach the -- that worked. I'm not --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: Say it, Dana.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Say it, say it.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Oh no. If you told me to jump off a bridge --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It rhymes with Brother Trucker.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: So, I think there's a real interesting thing about just the political savviness of somebody like a Talib versus someone like a Slotkin. So, Slotkin is also a freshman Democrat. She is in one of the districts that Trump won in 2016. She was a former CIA officer. Like she is -- a different type of person than Talib because she knew that if you -- votes for impeachment, it is very likely, she is going to lose in 2020. But she decided, this is what I'm going to do, I'm voting my conscience. I'm going to let the chips fall where they may. The difference is, if somebody like Talib, who is going to win in her district probably, well, maybe not her. But most of these Democrats are going to win no matter what. It doesn't matter. So, they're being really bad team players. And if they think that they need the majority in order to hold President Trump in check, they might have just written themselves off in 2020 and put their majority at risk for the benefit of somebody like Talib and not someone like a Slotkin who might lose.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: There you go. Interesting. Emily, bring it on home with some incredible analytical insight.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno, guest co-host
utterances.utterance: Okay. I think the media celebration and the left celebration is so sickening to me. And it's not like we didn't know already, but it just rendered everything transparent. So, after the impeachment debates, did you guys see Tom Nichols tweet where he said -- he calls it the, "rump party." "For the GOP is fast on their way to becoming the rump party of the south and the mountains." To which Jennifer Rubin replied, "And the non-college educated." And it is so offensive to me and it is so alienating and elitist that just drips out of that, the left in the mainstream media. And that's exactly why, as we always say, that people continue to support Trump, because of that feeling from them. And the notion that it's only the college educated that are allowed to participate in these proceedings and otherwise you don't understand. And then to kind of attach yourself to that fairness idea, it's so gross. And the smugness to, you know, that Talib, "We're going to impeach." I have never felt smug at a sentencing. I have never felt smug or celebrated when I'm sitting in prison, no matter what kind of monster I was sitting across from, with a few exceptions. It is always a really grave thing. And so, all of that, to me just belies the obvious. Final point, though. Remember, she's the one that that utilized her grandmother, right? As a token political issue and at the end of the day, we see right through her.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You've never not felt smug? Written all over --.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: He's got a smug mug.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: He's got a smug mug.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: Ooh, that's good.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: After racing to impeach Trump, Speaker Nancy Pelosi is pumping the brakes on sending articles to the Senate. That's next.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: The Democrats impeachment sham is getting even more outrageous. Remember when it was supposed to be quick? Now Nancy Pelosi is dragging her feet by waiting to send the articles of impeachment to the Senate. Pelosi melting down after being called out for it earlier.

utterances.speaker: Nancy Pelosi
utterances.utterance: Frankly, I don't care what the Republicans say, not on this subject.

utterances.speaker: Reporter Question
utterances.utterance: -- criticized Mitch McConnell --

utterances.speaker: Nancy Pelosi
utterances.utterance: Not on this subject. I said this is it. Any other questions on any of -- anybody want to talk about Mexico free trade agreement? Anybody care about that?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: [LAUGHS] She just impeaches the president and doesn't want to talk about it. Here's the president responding to impeachment.

utterances.speaker: Donald Trump
utterances.utterance: They're playing games. They don't want to put in their articles, their ridiculous, phony, fraudulent articles. And I think they're not allowed to that. I hear it's unconstitutional and a lot of other things. But they don't want to put them in because they're ashamed of them.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: And Republicans are mocking Pelosi.

utterances.speaker: Mitch McConnell
utterances.utterance: And Speaker Pelosi suggested that House Democrats may be too afraid, too afraid to even transmit their shoddy work product to the Senate. They said impeachment was so urgent that it could not even wait for due process, but now they're content to sit on their hands. This is really comical.

utterances.speaker: Kevin McCarthy
utterances.utterance: Now we have the only speaker of the house who is so embarrassed, that she admits the failure of this impeachment, that she will not even send it to the Senate.

utterances.speaker: Female Speaker
utterances.utterance: [LAUGHS]

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: All right. Juan, try to convince me --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- that this is some sort of brilliant tactical move. I just don't see it. I don't see how she has leverage, power. I don't see how holding them back gives her anything, results in anything. Explain it to me.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You think Trump wants impeachment just hanging around over his head?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Over his head? He's going to get acquitted. Who cares?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Oh, so that's what your assumption is. I see. Because that's what you just saw, was total spin coming from the Majority Leader McConnell.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: So, tell me what the point is?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: The point is that right now McConnell says that, you know, "This is a political proceeding," and he's 100 percent right. But he's also said that he has prejudged this. Lindsey Graham says he doesn't even want to see any evidence. They don't want any witnesses. Charles Schumer, the majority leader in the Senate, says he'd like to have people come forward who have firsthand knowledge.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Who cares what Schumer wants?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: They investigate in the House --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Okay, so --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- and then the Senate judges.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- no, no. The Senate --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: That's how it works --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- the Senate --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- in the Constitution, Juan.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- the Senate can set its own terms. They're going to have John Roberts, the Supreme Court chief justice, there. They can, in fact, call --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: And Schumer doesn't control the Senate.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- no, I agree, Republicans. Just like Democrats control the House --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: So --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- Republicans -- but you know what? There is a requirement, I think, that you have some sense of fairness and honesty, and look --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- there wasn't fairness in the House, Juan.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- I think there was.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: You're not getting it back. Greg --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: But I want to say -- but I don't think --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- Juan can't explain why it's a brilliant strategy.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- I just explained it to you.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Why? Because they're just going to keep them in Nancy's pocketbook --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- for the rest of year?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I mean, the idea of -- we've already dismissed the idea of "we demand more witnesses." If your case was so strong, why are you demanding more witnesses? And again, why wouldn't you capitalize on the momentum of this great achievement? Why? Because the momentum is going in reverse.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: And they know that. And that's why, that's why Trump is in an unusually good mood during this whole thing, because only his -- his numbers keep going up, but -- so, what this is, what they're going, what they're trying to say now is "We need to dig up more stuff." So, that's basically what they're saying is, as they've always said, "Impeach now, find the crime later." That's why, when you talk about fairness, no one listens because it was never fair because you guys started the day he was inaugurated. You've always been saying, "Impeach, impeach, impeach." You've mentioned it four times already, so.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I said -- no, no, I said they said that -- there are some people who raised this, and they said no to it.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: They were waiting, they were --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: But I just --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- "Impeach now, find the crime later." That's the, that's the --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: But I --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Emily, you know what it looks like --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- well, hang on. Let me just hash this point to Greg.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- let's just bring Emily in a little bit --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Hang on. Hang on.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- so we can move it on.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Let me just respond to Greg --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- on this because I think when you say rush, rush, rush, remember John Bolton. And not only John Bolton, Mark, Mack -- Mulvaney.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- yeah.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: All these guys said they have firsthand knowledge, but Trump said, "Don't testify. Send it to the courts." So, maybe Nancy Pelosi should just hold on and say, "Okay, we'll wait for the courts," --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Your case is too strong. You don't need witnesses.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible] yeah.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- oh.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's what I heard.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Oh. So, that's why we have an obstruction article of impeachment.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: It's not obstruction.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: So, wait. Nancy's going to now go to court and --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- and then he's not obstructing it --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Well --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- because [unintelligible] --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: [LAUGHS]

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You know what? It's beyond court.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I think you're erasing your articles as we speak, Juan.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: No, I --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Let's just talk about the --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- okay.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- is this P.R.? Because she obviously wants him to be impeached, but she doesn't want him to be acquitted. And that's the problem she faces.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Which is just another reason why this is so preposterous and so transparent. Everyone sees through this game. It is gamesmanship. This is not actual seeking justice. And we're talking about fairness. How is it fair to hold on to these articles? It's literally in the Constitution, the Sixth Amendment, that you have a right to a speedy trial. And yeah, this isn't a criminal defendant, per se. But why, if we hold -- as a procedural matter, if we hold as Americans that is so fundamental that it is processed quickly and efficiently, then all of a sudden, she just decides to hang onto things, let alone that it's a two-step process? And her baton should pass now to the chief justice. And I think, you know, we heard Majority Whip Rep. Clyburn today. He said, "Give him a fair trial and hang him."

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Like, those -- nothing about that indicates that there's an actual commitment to fairness. Because if so, too, then that testimony would have been so crucial, then yes, we would have waited for the court's decision.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: And we would have been slow walked forever.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: But the evidence would have been --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: One of the reasons the Democrats said they had to do this was because Trump was an imminent threat to the democracy and the upcoming 2020 election. What happened to the urgent threat?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: It was a pre-impeachment.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I have permission to make a sports analogy?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Oh my god.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Permission granted.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I've been trying to figure out, like, what am I missing? Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the house, is really smart, right? She's really, she's really strategic. And I cannot, I feel like -- am I missing something? Because it does seem like she has fumbled on the one-yard line.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: That's my only --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Very good.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That was your analogy?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I thought it was good.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Sports analogy, and I have another point to make. What they're telling the members that the consolation prize on the Democratic side is, well, well, now we get to go into 2020 and we will always be able to say that Donald Trump was impeached and that's what they really wanted. They want to have it in the ads. They want him to be labeled that way, and they watered down the two articles so much that abuse of power could be and every American thinks that every president abuses their power.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I mean, because we are Americans, we don't trust the power.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I guarantee you, if Trump turns this in and starts selling merchandise with best president ever and impeached, he's going --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: He could --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah he's going to make millions.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: He's already doing that, but I would just say with regard to Pelosi, you'd say, oh, shit, the Democrats are not doing anything but impeach. Well, look at the Mexican trade deal that went through, right?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Look at the deal that under the budget in one year.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Yeah so, she fumbled on the one yard line.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: No, she didn't fumble.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: And then President Trump picked up the ball and ran it back 99 yards for a touchdown.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Yes Dana.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, Dana you said, oh, you know what? The Democratic moderates oh, they're going to have trouble with her. Look at that all the moderates they got on board. Who's leaving? Mark Meadows.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Five, Dem Five Republicans just this month.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: A New Jersey Democrat.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: It was a bipartisan --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Justin Amash oh --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: It was a bipartisan vote against impeachment.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Technically it was.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Oh, get out of here.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Coming on the DOJ IG destroys the FBI over FISA abuses and refuses to rule out political bias. Details ahead.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: More alarming fallout in the FISA abuse scandal. Attorney General Bill Barr and DOJ Inspector General Michael Horowitz blasting the FBI over the botched handling of the Trump Russia probe. First, here's A.G. Barr calling out James Comey.

utterances.speaker: Martha MacCallum
utterances.utterance: He said, I was seven steps removed from what was going on. The director doesn't get involved in these kinds of things. The actual investigation, do you believe that?

utterances.speaker: William Barr
utterances.utterance: No. I think that the one of the problems with what happened was precisely that they pulled the investigation up to the executive floors and it was run and bird dogged by a very small group of very high level officials and the idea that this was seven layers below him is simply not true.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: All right you can watch more of that interview with the attorney general tonight on the story and DOJ Inspector General Michael Horowitz with some explosive testimony yesterday.

utterances.speaker: Rand Paul
utterances.utterance: Could you then specifically say the opposite that actually, in this instance, there actually was evidence of political bias and evidence of record changing that looks like malfeasance.

utterances.speaker: Michael Horowitz
utterances.utterance: There is evidence of both. I'm agree with you.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: But you definitely in both these investigations, you found political bias.

utterances.speaker: Michael Horowitz
utterances.utterance: We found through the text messages evidence of people's political bias. Correct.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: All right, Jesse, what are your thoughts on that bias? The evidence of bias in the process and then if you can talk about it, the Lisa Page's insurance policy explanation that she gave about it, essentially. Oh, that was an analogy.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Sure, off of Dana's sports analogy.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Oh no.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I would say this.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Please no.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: You have James Comey he botches two big time investigations, the Trump investigation and the Hillary Clinton investigation. That would be like a --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Buffalo Bills.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Umpire.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: All right. Blowing two World Series costing the Yankees both World Series against the Red Sox. All the calls go against the New York Yankees then all the umpires crew has their cell phones out and they all say, I hate the Yankees. I will do whatever I can do to stop the Yankees from winning and then you say, hey ump you guys bias. How dare you challenge our integrity. It just doesn't add up. These are not sloppy mistakes. This is intentional misconduct. You don't happen to forge a document. You don't accidentally conceal information from a judge. You intentionally deceive a judge in order to spy on a campaign. It's just so clear. I mean, look at some of these text messages. Trump's never going to become president, right? No, he's not we'll stop it. POTUS, Barack Obama, wants to know everything we're doing.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Quote the White House is running this. Just look at that and then look at the results and the bias just screams in your face. Now, Durham is looking at how all these things started. He's looking at whether it was started by Papadopoulos or that was just an excuse to ramp up an investigation that had already started. Who started the Russia collusion rumor? What was the bias at the FISA level? And he's also looking into the CIA, the DOJ, the NSA, the DOD. I can keep going.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Yeah, the NBA the NFL.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: He's looking at it all. Does he say this thing's finished? It's not finished until Durham says it's finished and he's a man of integrity.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah that's what you sad about the Horowitz report.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: The what Senate Democrats confirmed him, and he worked for a Democrat.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: This is what you said, when you oh the Horowitz reports, Comey's going to blow this whole thing. Watters you --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: No, I didn't.

utterances.speaker: Female Speaker
utterances.utterance: Actually, Juan, I did it.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: And it did blow the whole thing up?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: It did not because let me ask you, do you think that Horowitz's report is good or bad? Here's why I ask that question.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I think it's –

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You like the part where Horowitz goes after the FBI and says mistakes were made, and they were made. But you don't like the part where he says, you know what? No political bias in terms of the origins of the report or even the mistakes.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: He said he couldn't find evidence of political bias, because when he asks someone, "Are you politically biased?" they say, "no."

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: That's not true --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's true, Juan.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: No, what is true is when he looked into this case, he said, for example, with regard to the e-mails that you just talked about, people have personal opinions, but they did not either make the decision or exhibit it in their conduct that they're pro --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It's like flipping a coin 20 times and each time it lands on heads.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You don't you don't make the same mistake over and over again and have it not be rigged --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Reality's a problem --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You know it's rigged, you're smart enough to know it's rigged --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You can't pick or choose. You've got to say, is this report good or bad? You can't have part of it and then throw the rest of it out.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Juan, the report says the thing was crooked from the --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- If you don't see bias in what they did to the Trump campaign, what you're willfully blind to use a quote --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Trump's coat is blinding you, you're so close behind him.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: My future is so bright, I need shades.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You should get some.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Wow. That's a great phrase.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Dana, even the FISA court came out publicly and said essentially that --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: So this -- because of impeachment this hearing yesterday, which was actually pretty interesting in its own right, was overshadowed. And then at the end of the day, the FISA court, which is a secret court, they never say anything. They actually issue a letter saying, we are furious at the FBI. They are demanding a response by January 10th because they were lied to. That's what this report says. The Horowitz – Horowitz IG report says that they were lied to. So how can they do their job and protect all of us? Remember, Americans pay for these salaries. We pay for the intelligence. We pay for all of the technology that is used to help protect us from possible threats that are being coordinated from overseas. That's why you have a foreign intelligence surveillance court in the first place. And if that is ruined because of political bias or not so much political bias or incompetence, whatever it is, I think that FBI does have a lot to answer for. And I think Chris Wray ought to give a public speech and a press conference about it.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: In 2003, the Senate Oversight Committee already investigated the FISA court and said that they'd have a culture of not accepting criticism, i.e. what A.G. Barr said. And, also, 99 percent of the applications are approved. In contrast to what -- how Comey said, "Oh, it's a hard bar to cross." What are your thoughts?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I have no thoughts, Emily. I look at it this way. There are 17 errors all in one direction. It's bias, but it's not the kind of bias that we're used to. We're used to political bias or left versus right bias. This is a confirmation bias issue, whether it's a social worker or a discrimination attorney or a hate crime investigator, finding something means work to do. And so that defines your job. So, you -- like you see what you want to see. For example, may I use an analogy, please? If you have back pain and you go to an acupuncturist, or you go to a chiropractor, or you go to a massage therapist and the back pain goes away, all of them will believe that it was because of them. When, in fact, the back pain just went away because it usually does. So, it's like people, by the job that they do, believe that they're actually doing the right thing. That's why I'm not to -- this is biased. They hated Trump. They wanted him out. They thought he was a threat, so that bias confirmed all of these mistakes. So, I think that's fair.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: It is kind of strange that the Obama White House, though, doesn't get more attention.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's a crazy -- I keep forgetting about that. That's insane. He should be impeached. Why don't you do a retroactive impeachment? And find that birth certificate while you're at it. And that tan suit.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Waters
utterances.utterance: We're working on the birth certificate. I got people down there.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Oh my God. Oh lord.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I will save us. Amazon's Alexa is always listening to your conversation. Hopefully not this one, though. And now it wants to break up fights during Christmas. More on that ahead.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. New signs, big tech taking over our lives. Amazon's virtual assistant, Alexa, set to roll out a new feature for the holidays. If a debate with the family gets too heated, Jesse and I, for example, you can now have Alexa help change the subject. And face-to-face interaction? That's disappearing, too. New research finds we now spend more time having digital conversations than talking to each other in person. Greg?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Oh, my sister told me an amazing story about the disconnect between digital conversation and face-to-face interaction. So, she works out west and she was at a party, and there are a bunch of people there. And two guys nearly get in -- they get face-to-face in a savage fight. They are, like, going to -- getting to fisticuffs. They had to be separated. They had never met each other before. Then, when they get them apart, they realize they've been communicating every single day via e-mail at the company, and very congenial and had no idea who they were at the party. They almost kicked each other's butts because they've had always been talking digitally and never, ever met each other. I thought that was like a perfect example of how it would have -- normally, though, on digital you're more rude, but they didn't even know each other. I thought that was amazing.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Wait, so, then they got to a point about something else, you're saying, because they were friends over e-mail and then at the party --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: They didn't -- when they were talking, they didn't know they were those people. Isn't that creepy. It's like the Sixth Sense. It's like that movie.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I'm not sure I get that story because they didn't know each other. So what?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: They did, they did -- it's like you and me communicating by email every day, right.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: And then we're over at a bar and we don't know each other.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: And then I say something rude to you.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: And you say, "Who the hell are you?"

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Oh. And it would have moderated it if they knew they --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes, it escalated into a fight --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I see.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- because they didn't know who they were.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I see. Okay, Dana.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: What's wrong?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Okay, okay.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Why are you people laughing?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Dana, what about this idea that Alexa --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: What the hell?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- Alexa can help to resolve family arguments?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't want Alexa listening. I don't want anybody involved in my family. And then I thought, "Well, maybe some families need this, so why do I care?" Knock yourself out if you want to have an Alexa. That's good. I mean -- but I also think, you know, this is the end of the decade. Everything in the world is better. The fact that we're talking less is probably good.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: What do you think about --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Don't say that about The Five.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- that, Jesse? You think we could do better by not texting but actually face to face?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Well, I like talking --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: -- yeah. It's faster.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- face to face because the you can read people.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I know when someone's uncomfortable --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: [affirmative]

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- when I'm talking to them.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: And you don't --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I can see them wincing, I can see them smiling, I can see them responding. I don't know how my material's doing over text. I can't tell if an LOL actually means LOL.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I need to hear --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: -- you texted me.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- the L. Yeah, by accident last week. So, do you want to tell this story?

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Yes, we have to hear it.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: You want me --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: May I tell it?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- no, you tell it.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I can tell it?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: You're okay? Okay. So, I was listening, I was looking through something. I heard something about a great Santa event that's being held downtown. You've got to buy tickets. And it's really fun for kids, and it's near Jesse's apartment. So, I sent a text to him and to his fiancé, and I said, "Hey, this might be something you want to do with the girls. Just want to make sure it's on your radar screen because it's in your neighborhood." And they're like, "Oh, thanks. That's so great." And then I get another text from Jesse that says, "I miss you already." And I was like --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: It was not meant for you.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I mean, I was flattered.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: It was Saturday morning and I'm thinking --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I haven't seen you since Friday, Dana.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: But that was weird though because that was actually for Brian Kilmeade.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Dangerous.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Emily, what about, what about the idea that a computer could settle family disputes over the holidays?

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Well, to me, it's like international law where, for it to work, you have to subscribe to it. So, I can imagine if there's really a family fight and all of a sudden Alexa is like, "No, talk about this," that someone's going to be like, "I don't care. Let's, you know, toss it out the window."

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Yeah, Alexa.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Like, you need more of, like, one of those -- the pins where you pull it out of the thing, and it emits that high-pitched squeak where you're like --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I like the idea of Alexa settling disputes because you can just say, "Fact check that, Alexa."

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: [LAUGHS]

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: You want, you want one for The Five?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You got it.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yeah, we should get one.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Yes, we need one here, for sure.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Now, that would be, that would be an expensive device. Up next, dramatic video showing a teen girl being snatched off the street. But it turns out, this could be a hoax. Next on The Five.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: A nightmare scenario caught on tape, but could it be a hoax? A 16-year-old teen girl seen dragged into a car and kidnapped right in front of her mother sparked an Amber Alert and massive media attention. But now police sources telling Fox News that appears the girl made it all up, and she reportedly did it because of an overprotective mother. Emily, I know you pay a lot of attention to these kind of stories, and it was really scary to think that this had happened. But then on -- she was having problems with her mom, she doesn't want to move, could be a hoax.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Right. So, it seemed, from what we might know thus far, like it seems a typical teenage girl in angst with an overprotective mother, with the decisions that she doesn't agree with, and dating a guy she just wants to be with. But if this is true, that it's, indeed, a hoax, this is obviously an absolute, really unfathomable decision on her part. And I think the worst thing to me -- first of all, it's a, it's a felony charge; if this, in fact, is a staged crime, that's a felony, right? We all remember Jussie Smollett. And the worst part, to me, was that her mother was there at that time, and the report goes that she was holding on to her and, like, pulling on her, "No, no, no, no, no." And the trauma, I cannot imagine the trauma --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: -- that mom felt in that moment that she will never -- I think it would be hard for her to forgive her daughter.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: What do you think about that, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm looking at some of my sources right here. They say Adam Schiff is trying to hire her after this hoax. She's definitely credentialed to be on the Impeachment Committee after all that. And I would say obviously not true.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Jesse, she's not old enough to work in Congress. She's only 17.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, maybe she could be a page for him. Who knows, you know? I think that this boyfriend's obviously -- he's probably an amazing boyfriend --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Well, it was --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- to pull a stunt like that.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: -- well, okay. Look, it was reported that he's "23 years old, reputed Crips gangbanger, once arrested for murder," police sources said.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Maybe not the best boyfriend.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Not the greatest.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Maybe the mom was right on this one.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I think the mom --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Maybe read the story.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Oh. Oh, help us.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: -- Greg, I think the mom might have had good instincts.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes, very -- I'm pro-mom on this one and -- but you have to ask, why are there so many -- it feels like we're in the decade of the hoax.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: [affirmative]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: There's all these things. And I think we live in a time with accelerated social media and -- and in the prehistoric media, as well, reward victimhood. And I think that sometimes kids just read the environment and go, "This is one way to get out of something, get some attention." And I feel bad for the mom --

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: I feel --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- because she was fighting to save her kid. She was knocked to the ground.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I hope the guys that did that are put away, and she's got to do a little time.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Yeah, they --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: A little time. Juvie?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: -- the mother was planning, Juan, to uproot the family --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Juvie.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: -- and go back to Honduras with the daughter and she didn't, the daughter didn't want to leave the boyfriend, which --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Yeah. So, it seems to me like the kid made it up. I mean, I don't know for sure, but it looks that way. And I -- you know, as a result, I think a compassionate way to do this is to say that young lady needs a lot of help. Something's going on. It's dysfunction --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: -- and so does the mom --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: -- right.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: -- after going through that.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I think, especially after going and seeing your child yanked away. But I think there's some dysfunction and some upset both with the mom and the child.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Let me ask the parents on here, would you press charges?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: To respect her just say, oh, it's is that, you know.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Oh, hell yeah, I'm pressing charges. I'm not a parent.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: But you're a parent to the parents, would you guys press charges?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I would not. It's not a waste of public money just to get in it's like a domestic dispute.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: No press charges against the guys that carried it out.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Well, the guys were working for the apparently, again, apparently for the little girl.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: What a mess. That's not a good holiday story. Sad, but hopeful well, you know what? Everything turned out OK.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Did it Dana?

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: Hold up she is back with her mom.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: No Sports analogy.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: That is like when --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: No, don't do it.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: OK one more thing is up next.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It's a little strange, man. It's time for one more thing. All right my dates for Nashville that's March 22 are now available to go to Ggutfeld.gov, oh this is going to be... crazy. I got some special guests obviously with Tom Shillue it's going to kick butt. Now it's time for this. You know, it's going to be crazy.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: It's going to be amazing,

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You know what I'm saying? You know, we live in a time where the gender thing is fluid Dana, I don't know if you're aware that everybody's fluid. I don't even know what I identify as but over here, check out this cat, which I now identify as a bird. I mean, normally cats would eat the canary, but his case, he's trying to get him into a romantic mood.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: He's playing with his [LAUGHS]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: The birds that get it the hell away this is never going to work this is never going to work. But you know what? Love transcends all species and differences. And I would like to.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: That cat is so sweet.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: And he's licking his chops. I think he's playing with his food.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: But anyway.

utterances.speaker: Emily Compagno
utterances.utterance: He did a little like --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It's beautiful. And that's why [music plays], The greatest song you will ever hear. So, Jesse, speaking of animals.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Back by popular demand, Greg.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: The animals are great leash still on sale at the Fox News Shop just 15 bucks. You guys can afford it this country's economy is just so strong. Here is a little rookie man wearing the leash and we also have Jasper. Not as good looking on Jasper's rookie. But you know what? It's all about the fit. So, get your leash today at Shop.FoxNews.com. Also, we had our Christmas party at the Long Acre Tavern. Guess who's missing?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I was there.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Greg left early.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
